entries.meaning: A moving disturbance, or undulation, in the surface of a fluid.
examples: I dropped a small stone into the pond and watched the ripples spread.
The ebbing tide had left ripples in the sand.

entries.meaning: A sound similar to that of undulating water.
A style of ice cream in which flavors have been coarsely blended together.
examples: I enjoy fudge ripple ice cream, but I especially like to dig through the carton to get at the ripple part and eat only that.

entries.meaning: (electronics) A small oscillation of an otherwise steady signal.

verbs.description: ripple (third-person singular simple present ripples, present participle rippling, simple past and past participle rippled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move like the undulating surface of a body of water; to undulate.
(intransitive) To propagate like a moving wave.
(intransitive) To make a sound as of water running gently over a rough bottom, or the breaking of ripples on the shore.
(transitive) To shape into a series of ripples.
(transitive) To launch or unleash in rapid succession.
examples: Hearns' 'Mech rippled fifteen missiles. Austen watched the missiles go in. They smashed into a copse of trees, smashing the trunks aside.

description: From Middle English *ripelen, repulen, equivalent to rip +‎ -le (frequentative suffix).

verbs.description: ripple (third-person singular simple present ripples, present participle rippling, simple past and past participle rippled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To scratch, tear, or break slightly; graze

description: Compare German Low German Repel, Dutch repel, German Riffel, extended forms (with instrumental or diminutive -le) of Low German Repe (“ripple”), Dutch repe (“ripple”). Compare also Dutch repen, German reffen, Swedish repa (“to beat; ripple”).
The verb is from Middle English ripplen, rypelen. Compare Low German repelen, Dutch repelen, German riffeln.

entries.meaning: (textiles) An implement, with teeth like those of a comb, for removing the seeds and seed vessels from flax, broom corn, etc.

verbs.description: ripple (third-person singular simple present ripples, present participle rippling, simple past and past participle rippled)

entries.meaning: To remove the seeds from (the stalks of flax, etc.), by means of a ripple.
